attributes.comment:
I disagree with the amount of fee increase as proposed in the document. I think
the bottom line is the whole operation of USCIS should not be totally relied on the
applicants. A lot of the overhead expense is fundamentally coming from the
secuity measure in processing the document. It is necessary, however, and the
federal funding should come in when it involves national security. When it comes
to inflation, I really think the amount of increase is totally overwhelming and it is
more than enough to cover the basic cost. The other basic thing is how to
increase the operation efficiency of USCIS without dramtically increasing the
cost. How much man power is needed to actually get the application document
processed? How about cutting the number of employee when the applicant
number goes down? I think in general the budget proposal of USCIS is out of
control and then the bug is being pushed to the new immigrants.

What do you think if your driver's license fee has a 100% increase every two
years, if your DMV people tell you that's what they need to make the process of
getting the driver's license renewal even faster? Let people know how much your
staff get paid for getting the job done. If the applicants are really responsible for
all the cost incurred for the operation, let the whole process be transparent and let
people know it is operating in good efficiency like in a good private company. If
the mindset behind the fee increase is to discourage more legitimate applicants to
be lawful US citizen, that thought and action must be stopped immediately.

Jonathan Weng
Legal permanent resident
attributes.title: Comment Submitted By Jonathan C. Weng, University of Missouri
